metadata.title: Journal of Infection Risk Factors of COVID-19, SARS, and MERS: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

abstract.text: Objective: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic. This systematic review compares mortality risk factors including clinical, demographic and laboratory features of COVID-19, Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS). The aim is to provide new strategies for COVID-19 prevention and treatment. Methods: We performed a systematic review with meta-analysis, using five databases to compare the predictors of death for COVID-19, SARS and MERS. A random-effects model meta-analysis calculated odds ratios (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (95% CI). Results : 845 articles up through 11/4/2020 were retrieved, but only 28 studies were included in this meta-analysis. The results showed that males had a higher likelihood of death than females (OR = 1.82, 95% CI 1.56-2.13). Age (OR = 7.86, 95% CI 5.46-11.29), diabetes comorbidity (OR = 3.73, 95% CI 2.35-5.90), chronic lung disease (OR = 3.43, 95% CI 1.80-6.52) and hypertension (OR = 3.38, 95% CI 2.45-4.67) were the mortality risk factors. The laboratory indicators lactic dehydrogenase (OR = 37.52, 95% CI 24.68-57.03), C-reactive protein (OR = 12.11, 95% CI 5.24-27.98), and neutrophils (OR = 17.56, 95% CI 10.67-28.90) had stronger correlations with COVID-19 mortality than with SARS or MERS mortality. Consolidation and ground-glass opacity imaging features were similar among COVID-19, SARS, and MERS patients. Conclusions: COVID-19's mortality factors are similar to those of SARS and MERS.
Age and laboratory indicators could be effective predictors of COVID-19 mortality outcomes.

This study covered 845 articles retrieved up through 11/4/2020. In the end, only 28 studies were included in our meta-analysis. The results showed that male patients had higher incidence of death than female patients (OR = 1.82, 95% CI 1.56-2.13). Age (OR = 7.86, 95% CI 5.46-11.29) and diabetes comorbidity (OR = 3.73, 95% CI 2. 35-5.90), chronic lung disease (OR = 3.43, 95% CI 1.80-6.52), and hypertension (OR = 3.38, 95% CI 2.45-4.67) are the mortality risk factors. Laboratory indicators of lactic dehydrogenase (OR = 37.52, 95% CI 24.68-57.03), C-reactive protein (OR = 12.11, 95% CI 5.24-27.98), and neutrophils (OR = 17.56, 95% CI 10.67-28.90) have stronger correlations with COVID-19 mortality. Consolidation and ground-glass opacity image features are similar in COVID-19, SARS, and MERS patient. Cover Letter COVID-19's mortality factors are similar to those of SARS and MERS. Age and laboratory indicators could be effective predictors of COVID-19 mortality outcomes. This systematic review has been reported in the international Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (PROSPERO) database (CRD42020180929). . Phone: 22 Highlights  COVID-19 mortality risk factors were similar to those of SARS and MERS.  Advanced age, hypertension, diabetes, chronic lung disease, increased LDH, CRP, neutrophils and BUN and decreased albumin were positively correlated with COVID-19 mortality.  The laboratory indicators of poor outcomes with the highest degrees of difference were similar among the three coronavirus diseases.  Low lymphocyte subtype counts might be a factor in COVID-19 mortality. 22 SARS or MERS mortality. FIGREF3.text: STATA) as a basis for identifying the relevant literature up 107 through April 11, 2020. The search string was: ["SARS" OR "Severe Acute 108 Respiratory Syndrome virus" OR "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome related 109 coronavirus" OR "MERS" OR "Middle Acute Respiratory Syndrome related 110 coronavirus" OR "2019-nCoV" OR "novel coronavirus" OR "SARS-CoV-2" 111 OR "COVID-19"] AND ["prognosis" OR "prognostic factors" OR "factor, 112 prognostic"]. In addition, we manually searched the included articlesthe search using their titles and abstracts. In cases of disagreement, 116 a fifth investigator was consulted. A study's eligibility for inclusion in the 117 meta-analysis was based on the following selection criteria: (I) Studies 118 included patients infected by SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV, and MERS-CoV. (II) 119 Patients in the studies had clinical outcomes including death. (III) Studies 120 reported demographic characteristics, clinical manifestations, laboratory 121 indicators and imaging. (IV) Articles were written in either Chinese or English.

FIGREF4.text: survivors are substantial. Higher WBC counts and procalcitonin levels 311 indicated that a large proportion of deceased COVID-19 patients might have 312 had secondary bacterial infections. These secondary infections may be a factor 313 in mortality. Deceased COVID-19 patients had more severe lymphopenia than 314 patients who recovered, suggesting that a cellular immune deficiency state was 315 a factor in poor prognosis. Additionally, other laboratory abnormalities in 316 deceased patients included coagulation disorder (elevation of prothrombin time 317 and D-dimer), impaired liver and kidney function (mild or moderate elevation 318 of ALT, AST, total bilirubin, BUN, and creatinine), elevated inflammatory 319 markers (high sensitivity CRP and ferritin), and cytokine storm. Most notably, 320 deceased patients had higher LDH levels than patients who recovered. The D-321 dimer, high-sensitivity cardiac troponin I, serum ferritin, LDH, IL-6 levels and 322 lymphocyte counts were all elevated in COVID-19 non-survivors, compared 323 with survivors, throughout the clinical course and illness progression[14]. 324 Next, we identified increased LDH, CRP, and BUN levels and neutrophil 325 count. Decreased albumin was correlated with mortality in COVID-19 patients. 326 Neutrophils can form neutrophil extracellular traps which contribute to organ 327 damage and mortality in COVID-19[51]. The changes in CRP and albumin 328 levels might be due to the coronavirus increasing inflammation in the body, 329 leading to poor outcomes. The elevated LDH and BUN in deceased patients 330 might be due to heart or kidney injury caused by the coronavirus disease. In 331 addition, this systematic review has suggested that IL-6 level is an important 332 mortality factor in COVID-19 and SARS patients. The role of IL-6 in 333 predicting respiratory failure and identifying severe COVID-19 cases has been 334 reported[52,53]. The IL-6 level has also been positively associated with CRP, 335 LDH, ferritin, and D-dimer levels in COVID-

TABREF1.text: Fig. 1). Finally, there was considerable overlap in the studies in terms of 178 regions and hospitals. In order to prevent research redundancy, we selected the 179 28 studies with the largest samples for our meta-analysis. This resulted in a 180 total of 16,095 patients (COVID-19: 11,818 patients, 910 death; SARS: 3,292 181 patients, 336 death; MERS: 985 patients, 465 death), including 1,711 in-182 hospital death patients. The characteristics of the included 28 studies are 183 summarized in supplementary Table 1[14-41]. These included studies were 184 conducted in several coronavirus outbreak areas-Beijing, Guangdong, Shanxi, Hong Kong and Taiwan in China, and Toronto where SARS broke out (12 186 studies); Saudi Arabia and South Korea where MERS broke out (6 studies); China, Italy, South Korea and the United States where COVID-19 broke out 188 (10 studies). Among these studies, 11 were case-control studies, 13 were cohort 189 studies, and 4 were case series. The diagnostic criteria for COVID-19, SARS, 190 and MERS were laboratory diagnostics, clinical characteristics and 191 epidemiological investigation as issued by the World Health Organization 192 (WHO). We analyzed 31 factors in the meta-analyses (Table 1). The NOS for 193 observational case-control and cohort studies assessment were showed in 194 supplementary Table 1. The 28 included studies scored between 5 and 9. None 195of the studies was considered to be poor quality.Factors associated with COVID-19, SARS, and MERS mortalityFig. 3A) were found to have higher mortality rates for COVID-19, SARS, and 209 MERS. The OR for patients' mortality rates with comorbidities of diabetes, SARS, and MERS. Its results are representative.
